awd_titl_txt: Online Undergraduate Resource Fair for the Advancement and Alliance of Marginalized Mathematicians
awd_abstract_narration:
This project serves the national interest by providing undergraduate and graduate students in the mathematical sciences with “insider” knowledge that will allow them to make informed decisions about their educational and career choices. Specifically, this project will support the third offering of the Online Undergraduate Resource Fair for the Advancement and Alliance of Marginalized Mathematicians, a two-day online conference.  Building from two prior offerings in 2020 and 2021 that involved 350 and 400 participants, respectively, the 2022 conference will include six main activities for participating students: (1) Our Stories talks, where recent PhD recipients will share their experiences; (2) crash courses that provide brief overviews of fields of mathematics common in undergraduate research; (3) a summer opportunities panel; (4) a student experiences panel; (5) two plenary presentations; and (6) two virtual networking lunches.  

Too often, students can be excluded from educational and career opportunities simply because they are not “in the know”, be that due to insufficient mentorship, underdeveloped institutional advising systems, or other circumstances. This is a particularly common challenge for individuals from low-income backgrounds, first-generation students, and students from populations that have historically been underrepresented in the mathematical sciences. This conference looks to provide important mentoring and networking opportunities to promote positive and inclusive access to opportunities for all students.  The conference builds upon three pillars: (1) sharing information about resources and opportunities through conference presentations and panel discussions; (2) providing access to role models and representation through a careful selection of speakers with diverse identities and experiences and a history of supporting students; and (3) providing access to networking opportunities. A participant overview and an assessment of the conference’s effectiveness will be conducted using a registration form, a Zoom meeting report, a post-conference survey immediately after the conference, and a post-conference survey four months after the conference. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Online Undergraduate Resource Fair for the Alliance and Advancement of Marginalized Mathematicians (OURFA2M2) is a two-day virtual conference aimed at undergraduate mathematics students from marginalized backgrounds. The conference was held virtually on November 19-20. The confereces are held virtually in order to be widely accessible. We use the term marginalized backgrounds to include but not limit to students considered to be part of an underrepresented minority group in mathematics, LGBTQ+ students, female students, community college students, and first generation college students. The goals of the conference are to (1) inform students about resources and opportunities that will help them develop their careers, (2) represent and uplift marginalized mathematicians who will be role models for conference participants, and (3) provide access to networking opportunities.

There were 225 participants for this conference and 305 unique users. The unique users were due to three main contributing factors. First, is that many users did not log into zoom from any account when they attended. Secondly, some logged into their personal accounts, which did not match their registration and with best data sorting we could not find matches. Lastly, there were also those who attended but did not register by means of a shared link from a friend. While there was an option to only allow those to join from a safe list, we thought it best to allow everyone the opportunity to join how ever they would like and the conference to be as accessible to as many as possible.

851 people registered for the conference ( last year 403, 111 % increase), and 93.5% reported that they were attending OURFA²M² for the first time (last year there was 85% first time attendees). The registrants came from more than 100 unique educational institutions and had the follow professional identities:

-Undergraduate - 80.7% ( 71.7% in 2021)

- Graduate - 6.5% (8.4% in 2021)

- Post-Doc - .8% (3.5% in 2021)

- Professor - 8.8% (11.4% in 2021)

- Other - 3.2% ( 5% in 2021) (e.g. industry professionals, independent researchers, nonprofit organizers, etc.)

81.3% of all registrants reported that they identified with at least one of the marginalized groups we have listed below. There is overlap between identities such that, paired with the identities are the percentages of those who identified as each category. That is, each percentage is listed independently out of 100.

Our goal was to invite qualified, experienced speakers from a range of diverse backgrounds. We used several avenues to identify potential speakers, including: personal knowledge of mathematics professionals; nominations and recommendations from mathematics professionals working to increase the representation and advancement of underrepresented minority students in math; nominations and recommendations from our social media and email list networks; and biographical descriptions of mathematicians. The biographical resources utilized for the speaker selection include Mathematically Gifted and Black, The 500 Queer Scientists Project, The Spectra Outlist, Lathisms, Indigenous Mathematicians, The Math Alliance’s mentor list, Mathematicians of the African Diaspora, and the AMS Living Proof Blog. The conference consisted of seven different session types: Our Stories Talks, Crash Courses, Plenary Talks, Networking Lunches, the Opportunities Panel, the Experiences Panel, and a Resource Presentation.

In the months following the conference, we offered three skill-focused workshops, each 90 minutes in length, designed to help students gain access to and succeed in opportunities they learned about at the conference. The Math REU Application Workshop was held on January 21st, 2023. In this workshop, we discussed how and why to apply to Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) programs, shared our personal experiences in REU programs, and answered questions. Furthermore, we created a temporary Discord server (an online communication platform) for participants to ask questions and connect with other applicants. 94 individuals registered for this workshop, over 60 attended and we have 30 active members in a discord channel from 22 this workshop (Discord is a modern application version of an internet forum). The LaTeX Workshop was led by Alvaro Carbonero, Bowen Li, and Luke Seaton on Saturday, April 8th 2023. In this workshop, we gave a 90-minute introductory lesson to LaTeX. We divided the content into three sections: LaTeX essentials, LaTeX advanced, and making a Beamer presentation. Furthermore, we designed small LaTeX exercises and subsequently divided the audience into groups of 6 to 8 students to work on them. This way, we could go from group to group and more personally check on the progress of the participants. 79 individuals registered for this workshop.

Overall we were very pleased with the outcomes of this project and will remain to offer the conference and addtional resources for out target audiences. The data collected from the project has proven that the conference is successful and quite beneficial to undergraduate math students and faculty. The feedback that we have received will also help shape future conferences and other offerings.

Modified by: Kiera L Palma
